intro: Crataegus perjucunda, commonly known as the Florida hawthorn, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows to a height of 3–10 meters and features thorny branches with opposite, ovate to elliptical leaves. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers in the spring, which are followed by red to orange berries in the fall. Its botanical characteristics include pinnate stipules and a generally compact, spreading growth habit. It is often found in moist soils along stream banks and in wetlands.
